G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this proceeding pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and G.L. c. 215, § 3, in that this is a Complaint for Modification of an existing custody and parenting time order involving a minor child under the jurisdiction of the Middlesex Probate and Family Court.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this proceeding pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and G.L. c. 215, § 3, in that this is a Complaint for Modification of an existing custody and parenting time order involving a minor child under the jurisdiction of the Middlesex Probate and Family Court.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this proceeding pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and G.L. c. 215, § 3, in that this is a Complaint for Modification of an existing custody and parenting time order involving a minor child under the jurisdiction of the Middlesex Probate and Family Court.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 6.proposition: Venue in the Middlesex Probate and Family Court is proper because the original judgment and custody orders were entered in this Court, and the parties and the Child reside within its territorial jurisdiction.

Pearson v. Board of Health of Chicopee,.raw_text: Pearson v. Board of Health of Chicopee, 402 Mass. 797 (1988)
Pearson v. Board of Health of Chicopee,.proposition: Since entry of the 2018 Order, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the Child’s welfare and the appropriateness of the existing parenting schedule, such that modification is now warranted and in the Child’s best interests.
Pearson v. Board of Health of Chicopee,.case_name: Pearson v. Board of Health of Chicopee
Pearson v. Board of Health of Chicopee,.support_reasoning: The case is about enforcement of Massachusetts’ open meeting law and whether attorney’s fees can be awarded under a private attorney general theory or under G. L. c. 231, § 6F. It does not address family law, custody, parenting schedules, material and substantial changes in circumstances, or the best interests of a child. Therefore, it provides no support or authority for the claimed proposition regarding modification of a parenting schedule.
Pearson v. Board of Health of Chicopee,.relevant_excerpt: “The board of health (board) of Chicopee appeals from a judgment invalidating two meetings alleged to have been held in violation of the open meeting law. See G. L. c. 39, § 23B (1986 ed.)… As part of the judgment, the judge ordered that the board pay the plaintiffs $3,050.18 in attorneys’ fees and costs. The propriety of this award is the sole issue on appeal.”

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: Since entry of the 2018 Order, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting the Child’s welfare and the appropriateness of the existing parenting schedule, such that modification is now warranted and in the Child’s best interests.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modification of a parenting schedule based on a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting a child’s welfare. Schuler is an alimony and child support modification case focused on the payor’s financial circumstances, ability to pay, earning capacity, and assets; it does not involve custody, parenting time, or modification of a parenting schedule. While it recites the general rule that modification requires a material change in circumstances, it does so in the context of support obligations, not parenting or visitation, so it is not accurate authority for the specific proposition stated.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). Hinds v. Hinds, 329 Mass. 190, 191-192 (1952). In this case, the judge held that Chester did not prove the requisite change of circumstances.”

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: While the Child’s wishes are not controlling, they are entitled to some weight consistent with his age and maturity.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The court squarely addresses the role of a child’s wishes in removal/custody decisions and states that, particularly for young children, their views should not be given particular weight, while still recognizing that such views may have constitutional and legal significance and must be considered along with other interests. This aligns with the proposition that the child’s wishes are not controlling but are entitled to some weight consistent with age and maturity, even though here the court emphasizes that these particular children are young and thus their wishes carry limited weight.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: Even if the views of a child as to where he or she should live have constitutional significance (although generally such views of young children should not be given particular weight [see Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 820 (1981)]), and even if in a custody dispute one parent may properly assert constitutional rights of a minor child, this case does not present the constitutional question. In any event, even if a young child’s preference not to leave the country is entitled to recognition as a constitutional right, the child’s interest must be considered in conjunction with the rights of the parents and the interests of the Commonwealth.

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 268 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: While the Child’s wishes are not controlling, they are entitled to some weight consistent with his age and maturity.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly notes that the child expressed a preference to live primarily with his mother, acknowledges that such a preference is "[a]lthough not dispositive of the custody issue," yet treats it as a relevant factor that "at the very least" suggests how the child might adjust to a custodial arrangement. This reflects the principle that the child’s wishes are not controlling but are entitled to some weight consistent with the circumstances, including age and maturity.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: "In addition, we note that Caleb expressed to the guardian ad litem at the outset of the investigation his preference to reside primarily with his mother, and he reiterated this preference at the conclusion of the investigation, shortly before trial. Although not dispositive of the custody issue, Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738-739 (1996), these factors, at the very least, suggest that Caleb might quickly readjust to living with his mother during the week, and visiting his father on weekends and during part of each school vacation."

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: A more typical, developmentally appropriate schedule for an eight‑year‑old includes longer blocks of time and regular overnights with the non‑primary parent where feasible, to foster continuity, stability, and a meaningful parent‑child relationship, provided it is in the Child’s best interests.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.proposition: A more typical, developmentally appropriate schedule for an eight‑year‑old includes longer blocks of time and regular overnights with the non‑primary parent where feasible, to foster continuity, stability, and a meaningful parent‑child relationship, provided it is in the Child’s best interests.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.support_reasoning: The opinion is about standards for relocation in joint physical custody cases and the best‑interests analysis under a removal statute. It does not discuss what is a typical or developmentally appropriate parenting-time schedule for an eight‑year‑old, nor does it endorse longer blocks of time or regular overnights as a normative schedule. Any reference to contact with both parents is in the context of relocation and preserving joint physical custody, not prescribing age‑appropriate time blocks or overnights. Therefore it does not support the specific proposition cited.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u20.relevant_excerpt: "Shared physical custody contemplates that ‘a child shall have periods of residing with and being under the supervision of each parent . . . [assuring] . . . frequent and continued contact with both parents.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. ... Where physical custody is shared and neither parent has a clear majority of custodial responsibility, the child’s interests will typically ‘favor protection of the child’s relationships with both parents because both are, in a real sense, primary to the child’s development.’"

Cooper v. Cooper, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 721,.raw_text: Cooper v. Cooper, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 721, 725–26 (2021)
Cooper v. Cooper, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 721,.proposition: The parents’ agreement that modification is appropriate, while not binding on the Court, is further evidence that the parties themselves recognize the substantial change in circumstances and the benefits to the Child of a revised schedule.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10(a).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, any order regarding custody or parenting time must serve the best interests of the child.

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, any order regarding custody or parenting time must serve the best interests of the child.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in custody cases the “governing principle” and “dominating rule” is the welfare of the child and cites prior Massachusetts precedents for that rule. Although the case speaks in terms of “welfare” rather than the exact phrase “best interests,” Massachusetts law uses those concepts interchangeably in this context. The court affirms a custody/visitation order based on that standard, so it supports the proposition that such orders must serve the child’s best interests.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409\u2.relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ We repeated that same language in Jenkins v. Jenkins, 304 Mass. 248, 250 (1939), and added: ‘In providing for the custody of a minor child… the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, any order regarding custody or parenting time must serve the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly characterizes the governing standard in custody matters as the “best interests of the child” and applies that standard to both legal and physical custody, including structuring parenting time. The court traces the historical and statutory basis of the best-interests standard in Massachusetts and reaffirms that custody awards will not be sustained unless all relevant factors bearing on the child’s best interests have been weighed, thereby supporting the proposition that custody and parenting-time orders must serve the child’s best interests.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002) (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’).”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–05 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: In determining the Child’s best interests, the Court may consider, among other factors: the Child’s age and needs; the Child’s relationship with each parent; the capacity of each parent to provide for the Child’s needs; the pattern of care; the Child’s adjustment to home, school, and community; and the stability of the proposed arrangements.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly states that custody determinations must be guided by the child’s best interests and references factors like parental fitness, primary caretaker status, and the children’s welfare, but it does not set out or discuss the specific, itemized list of factors in the claimed proposition (age and needs, relationship with each parent, pattern of care, adjustment to home/school/community, stability of arrangements). Those factors are implicit in the judge’s analysis (e.g., focus on the primary nurturing parent, minimizing disruption, and parental conflict), but the case does not expressly articulate or adopt that multifactor test. Thus it only indirectly reflects, rather than clearly establishes, the detailed proposition stated.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: The judge found the wife has been the “primary nurturing parent” and “primary caretaker” and that the children have the “strongest bond” with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.proposition: Father now has the demonstrated ability to provide safe, appropriate overnight care for the Child in a suitable residence, including a separate bedroom and routine structure, which directly addresses past concerns that led to the prohibition on overnights.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns appellate review of a custody award in the context of domestic violence and the need for explicit findings on the effects of that violence on the child. It does not address, factually or legally, a father’s subsequent demonstrated ability to provide safe, appropriate overnight care, the adequacy of his residence, or modification of an earlier prohibition on overnights. The proposition describes a factual improvement and suitability of a current residence, which this decision neither discusses nor uses as a legal basis for any ruling.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.relevant_excerpt: "We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below 'fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.'... The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother.... Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings...."

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 31A, 31B.proposition: There is no known safety, abuse, neglect, or substance‑abuse concern that would make increased or overnight parenting time with Father contrary to the Child’s best interests under G.L. c. 208, §§ 31A, 31B or under G.L. c. 209A.

G.L. c. 209A.proposition: There is no known safety, abuse, neglect, or substance‑abuse concern that would make increased or overnight parenting time with Father contrary to the Child’s best interests under G.L. c. 208, §§ 31A, 31B or under G.L. c. 209A.

Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 61.proposition: A revised parenting plan will be more developmentally appropriate, less disruptive academically, and better aligned with the Child’s expressed wishes, all of which are consistent with the Child’s best interests under Massachusetts law.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 61.support_reasoning: The case is a care-and-protection decision about parental unfitness and permanent commitment to the Department of Social Services; it does not discuss crafting or revising a parenting plan, developmental appropriateness of different custodial schedules, academic disruption, or aligning custody arrangements with a child’s expressed preferences. Its best‑interests analysis focuses on safety, parental unfitness, and the need for a stable and safe environment, not on comparative evaluation of alternative parenting plans. Therefore it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 61.relevant_excerpt: “The judge adopted the opinion of the psychologist at Children’s Hospital Medical Center, that the son needed an emotionally stable home environment unavailable to him in the home of his parents… The judge could properly have concluded that committing the children to the custody of the department would be in their best interest.” (396 Mass. at 615, 620).

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.proposition: A revised parenting plan will be more developmentally appropriate, less disruptive academically, and better aligned with the Child’s expressed wishes, all of which are consistent with the Child’s best interests under Massachusetts law.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.support_reasoning: The case applies and explains the Massachusetts ‘best interests of the child’ standard in an adoption/placement dispute, but it does not discuss a “revised parenting plan,” academic disruption, or the child’s own expressed wishes. Its analysis centers on weighing stability and existing attachments against a prospective caretaker’s superior ability to address the child’s developmental needs, not on school schedules or honoring the child’s preferences in a parenting-plan context. Thus it provides only very general best‑interests background and does not specifically support the detailed proposition stated.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 225\u20.relevant_excerpt: “Once the judge concluded that parental unfitness was established, he correctly determined that the central question was whether it was in Hugo’s best interests to remain with his foster mother or to be transferred to the care and custody of his aunt. G. L. c. 210, § 3 (c). The ‘best interests of a child’ is a question that presents the trial judge ‘with a classic example of a discretionary decision.’… Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.”

Bercume v. Bercume, 428 Mass. 635, 642\u.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, this Court “may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care, custody, and maintenance of the minor children” upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where the modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.
Bercume v. Bercume, 428 Mass. 635, 642\u.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with modification of alimony under G.L. c. 208, §§ 34 and 37, not modification of custody or child-related orders under G.L. c. 208, § 28 or G.L. c. 209C, § 20. Although it does recite the general standard that a party seeking to modify a support or alimony judgment must show a material change in circumstances, it does so in the context of alimony only and does not reference or interpret §§ 28 or 209C, or speak specifically to judgments about care, custody, and maintenance of minor children. Thus it is not proper authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Bercume v. Bercume, 428 Mass. 635, 642\u.relevant_excerpt: “A party seeking to modify a judgment for alimony or child support ‘must demonstrate a material change in circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.’ Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981), citing Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). ‘In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances’ (emphasis added). Schuler v. Schuler, supra at 370.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28A.proposition: To the extent necessary, Mother also requests that the Court make such ancillary orders as may be required to implement the modified parenting schedule, including, if applicable under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 208, § 28A, any corresponding adjustment to support that the Court finds appropriate based on the revised parenting time, the parties’ incomes, and the Massachusetts Child Support Guidelines (without altering Mother’s primary physical custody status).

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: Find that modification of the existing custody and parenting‑time provisions is necessary and in the best interests of the Child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; and applicable case law;
